challenge.description: Formation of impurities during synthesis at low temperatures.
challenge.impact: Impurities can negatively affect the structural and electrochemical properties of the material.

solution.description: Use of carboxylic acids (citric and succinic acid) as fuels to assist in decomposition of metal complexes at low temperatures.
solution.methodology: Carboxylic acid-assisted wet-chemical synthesis with heating above 400°C.
solution.effectiveness: Successfully yielded impurity-free LiMn2−yCoyO4 powders when heated above 400°C.

evidence.data: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves showed decomposition of precursors and formation of single-phase materials above 400°C.

context.material_properties: Spinel structure with high purity required for electrochemical stability.
context.experimental_conditions: Heating in air at 400–700°C for 48 hours.
context.application_relevance: High-purity materials are critical for stable lithium-ion battery performance.

challenge.description: Broadening of XRD diffraction peaks with increasing cobalt content.
challenge.impact: Broadening indicates microstrain and smaller crystallite sizes, which can affect material performance.

solution.description: Analysis of peak broadening using Scherrer’s equation and strain calculations to quantify crystallite size and microstrain.
solution.methodology: X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis combined with least-squares refinement.
solution.effectiveness: Provided detailed insights into the structural changes and confirmed the relationship between cobalt substitution and microstrain.

evidence.data: XRD patterns showed systematic peak broadening with increasing cobalt content, and calculated crystallite sizes ranged from 200 to 380 nm.

context.material_properties: Spinel structure with cobalt substitution affecting lattice parameters.
context.experimental_conditions: XRD measurements performed on powders synthesized at 700°C.
context.application_relevance: Understanding structural changes is essential for optimizing battery performance.

challenge.description: Reduction in initial charge capacity with increasing cobalt content.
challenge.impact: Lower initial capacity reduces the energy density of the battery.

solution.description: Optimization of cobalt substitution level to balance capacity retention and stability.
solution.methodology: Electrochemical testing of various compositions (0 ≤ y ≤ 1) to identify optimal cobalt content.
solution.effectiveness: LiMn1.8Co0.2O4 showed improved cycling stability with minimal capacity fading (<5% at 35 cycles) while maintaining reasonable capacity.

evidence.data: LiMn1.8Co0.2O4 achieved 101 mAh/g with excellent cycling stability compared to native LiMn2O4.

context.material_properties: Cobalt substitution suppresses Jahn-Teller distortion and enhances cycling stability.
context.experimental_conditions: Electrodes cycled in the voltage range of 2.8–4.4 V at 22°C.
context.application_relevance: Improved cycling stability is critical for long-lasting lithium-ion batteries.

challenge.description: Phase transition near ambient temperature in undoped LiMn2O4.
challenge.impact: Phase transition leads to structural instability and capacity fading during cycling.

solution.description: Cobalt substitution to suppress the Jahn-Teller distortion and stabilize the spinel structure.
solution.methodology: Substitution of Mn3+ ions with Co3+ ions to increase the average Mn valency and reduce distortion.
solution.effectiveness: Phase transition was suppressed, and cycling stability was significantly improved for Co-substituted materials.

evidence.data: LiMn1.8Co0.2O4 showed no phase transition near ambient temperature and exhibited stable cycling performance.

context.material_properties: Spinel structure with Jahn-Teller distortion in Mn3+ ions.
context.experimental_conditions: Electrochemical cycling in the voltage range of 2.8–4.4 V.
context.application_relevance: Structural stability is essential for reliable battery operation over extended cycles.
